persons.name: Carl WilhelmScheele
persons.description: Swedish-German pharmaceutical chemist. One of the discoverers of what would later be called oxygen (1771) as well as other chemical elements including what Davy renamed chlorine.

persons.name: DanielRutherford
persons.description: Scottish physician, chemist, and botanist who isolated nitrogen in 1772.

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: Joseph LouisGay-Lussac
persons.description: French chemist and physicist, known mostly for his discovery that water is made of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen by volume (with Alexander von Humboldt), for two laws related to gases, and for his work on alcohol-water mixtures. Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Martin afPontin
persons.description: Swedish court physician. Worked with Berzelius on following up Davy's work in electro-chemistry.

persons.name: Thomas JohannSeebeck
persons.description: Born to wealthy German parents in what is now Estonia. Worked on the electro-magnetism before discovering thermo-electricity in 1822.

persons.name: Jöns JacobBerzelius
persons.description: Swedish chemist. He discovered the chemical elements cerium and selenium, and was the first to isolate silicon, thorium, titanium, and zirconium. A rival of Davy's whom he met a few times.

persons.name: JosephPriestley
persons.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

persons.name: Joseph LouisGay-Lussac
persons.description: French chemist and physicist, known mostly for his discovery that water is made of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen by volume (with Alexander von Humboldt), for two laws related to gases, and for his work on alcohol-water mixtures. Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: JohnDalton
persons.description: Mancunian chemist and natural philosopher who lectured at the Royal Institution. He formulated a version of the atomic theory of matter much disliked by Davy. FRSL.

persons.name: Carvanas
persons.description: Unidentified.

persons.name: RamonLlull
persons.description: Catalonian philosopher, theologian, poet, missionary, Christian apologist.

persons.name: Abū MūsāJābir ibn Ḥayyān
persons.description: the purported author of a large number of works in Arabic, often called the Jabirian corpus. His name is often latinized to Gebir or Geber.

persons.name: ThomasBrowne
persons.description: Seventeenth-century writer, especially on the natural world.

persons.name: EdwardKelley
persons.description: English alchemist and associate of John Dee.

persons.name: EdwardDyer
persons.description: English courtier, poet and alchemist.

persons.name: Torbern OlafBergman
persons.description: Swedish chemist and mineralogist. At some point Davy acquired a set of letters from Bergman to Franz Schwediaur written in the 1780s which are retained in the Royal Institution (RI MS HD/27/A). ForMemRSL.

persons.name: WilliamHiggins
persons.description: Nephew of Bryan Higgins. Professor of Chemistry at the Dublin Society where he proposed a theory of chemical atomism. Met Davy in London who supported Higgins's claim to the atomic theory over that of John Dalton. FRSL.

persons.name: Johannes JacobWecker
persons.description: Swiss physician and philosopher, best known for his work in the history of alchemy.

places.name: St Stephen-in-Brannel
places.description: St Stephen-in-Brannel is a civil parish and village in mid Cornwall.

places.name: Cornwall
places.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

persons.name: Claude LouisBerthollet
persons.description: French Chemist. ForMemRSL.

places.name: Rowley Hills
places.description: A range of hills in the West Midlands, England.

persons.name: Jean-BaptisteBiot
persons.description: French mathematician, physicist and astronomer; Professor of Physics at the Collège de France. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Dominique François JeanArago
persons.description: French mathematician, physicist, astronomer and political liberal. Davy presented him with the Copley Medal in 1825. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: ErasmusDarwin
persons.description: Physician and natural philosopher who was member of the Lunar Society and friend of Priestley and Watt; also a correspondent with Beddoes. FRSL.

places.name: Banská Štiavnica
places.description: Banská Štiavnica is a town in central Slovakia, in the middle of an immense caldera created by the collapse of an ancient volcano.

places.name: Hungary
places.description: a landlocked country in Central Europe. Its capital, Budapest, is bisected by the Danube River.

places.name: Andes
places.description: Mountain range in western South America.
